ygData.subject: Re: [rest-discuss] How to GET a  for editing in RESTful design?

Subject: Re: [rest-discuss] How to GET a <form> for editing in RESTful design?
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=86707282; y=KTbBWgj4AXzY4grUCJyqfHir1Gek8aZy-jO_1a3FOMZE884qMIE2FZTp
X-Yahoo-Profile: chappie_mischko

Jeoff Wilks wrote:
> Scott,
> 
> I know exactly what you were asking. Since these other guys are waxing 
> too theoretical, I'm stepping in with some practical examples.  :)
> 
> 1. In my current work I'm using URLs like this:
> /entries  -  view entries collection
> /entries/1  -  view entry 1
> /forms/entries  -  html form to add a new element to entries
> /forms/entries/1  -  edit entry 1
> 
> 2. In Zope/Plone I seem to remember seeing something like this:
> /entries  -  view collection
> /entries/1  -  view entry 1
> /entries/new  -  new entry (form)
> /entries/1/edit  -  edit entry 1
> 
> 3. In Trac (ticket system - see trac.edgewall.com 
> <http://trac.edgewall.com>) they use:
> /report  -  predefined SQL reports
> /query  -  a form and report are displayed at the same time
> /ticket/1  -  display ticket 1 - html on top, editing form on bottom

These appear to me to not be RESTful.  I understand that you're supposed to 
use only one URL for a resource whether to view, update, or delete it. 
Perhaps a different URL to create a new resource.  So having a seperate URL to 
get the form from seems unRESTful.  I'm no expert on REST and still climbing 
the learning curve here on RESTful design.  That's what I've found so far.

So, I'd want to GET, PUT, or DELETE to /entries/1 and I'd want to POST to 
/entries (or maybe /entries/new but "/new" seems unnecessary as there would be 
no other time to POST to /entries except when creating a new one so "/new" 
seems like fluff).

Scott
